bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 163, Number 163 (Wednesday, October 11, 2017)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. VARGAS:H.R. 4026.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:(1) To regulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and amongthe several States, and with the Indian Tribes, as enumeratedin Article I, Section 8, Clause 3 of the U.S. Constitution;and(2) To make all laws which shall be necessary and properfor carrying into execution the foregoing powers, and allother powers vested by this Constitution in the government ofthe United States, or in any department or officer thereof, ,as enumerated in Article I, Section 8, Clause 18 of the U.S.Constitution.[Page H7975]

item.name: Indigenous Peoples of the United States Subcommittee
Indigenous Peoples of the United States Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Indian, Insular and Alaska Native Affairs.
Referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources.

Pala Band of Mission Indians Land Transfer Act of 2017

This bill directs the Department of the Interior to take land in San Diego County, California, into trust for the benefit of the Pala Band of Mission Indians, if the tribe transfers title to that land to the United States. The land is made part of the Pala Indian Reservation.

No gaming may be conducted on the land.

item.title: To take certain land located in San Diego County, California, into trust for the benefit of the Pala Band of Mission Indians, and for other purposes.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
